prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Science Goal Band 6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Mapping SO2 and SO across Io's disk to determine their relative contributions and source regions. Determine the gas temperature and column abundances from observations of different line transitions.

prj:TemporalParameters.prj:note: Io should be observed near elongation. All relevant times in C36-6n (July-August 2016) are in indicated. Second observations should fall in a window approximately n*21.228 hrs after first observations, with n=1,3,5,7,9,11, -- etc

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
In Band 6 we will observe SO2 and SO simultaneously to investigate the spatial distributions of each gas, and potential differences between them. The frequencies of the transitions to be observed are listed in Table 1. As shown, the line strengths at these frequencies are different for each transition; these differences are essential as they enable us to determine both the atmospheric structure and column abundances through radiative transfer modeling. We were able to add one NaCl line in Band 6; this line has not been observed before with ALMA. Since we will observe Io at different elongations in band 6 and 7, the observation of NaCl will contribute to our understanding of the spartial distribution of NaCl.
A spectral (Hanning-smoothed) resolution of 122 kHz is needed to resolve the line, essential for both radiative transfer modeling and to determine the Doppler shift in the line. This worked well in Cycle 0, and should not be degraded.

The high spectral resolution, 122 kHz, required for our modeling results in a data rate of 24.42 MB/s, which exceeds the policy value of 12 MB/s by a factor of 2. Unfortunately, we cannot lower the spectral resolution without diminishing the scientific return.

We request the C36-6n array to both get a high spatial resolution (0.13'') and simultaneously see the entire disk (~1'' across). This spatria resolution is neeeded to determine potential differenes in the location of SO2 an SO gases, and connect them to volcanoes on Io, as will be observed quasi-simultaneously in the infrared, at spatial resolutions of ~0.05-0.1'' (Gemini, VLT, Keck).
With observations spread out over 2 hrs in time, longitudes will be smeared over 16 deg, or 0.16'' at disk-center. This is of the order of our spatial resolution. We will correct for longitudinal smearing both by making maps over shorter time intervals, deproject the maps, and combine them properly shifted in longitude. We will al so attempt to correct the UV data, building on our longitude-resolved Jupiter work (see Sault et al., 2004, Icarus 168, 336).

We request the C36-6n array to both get a high spatial resolution (0.1-0.15'') and simultaneously see the entire disk (~1'' across). We request a frequency resolution of 122 kHz. Using Cycle 0 data and our model calculations (Figs. 2, 3) as guidelines, we request a sensitivity of ~4 mJy/beam (4-5 K in 0.13'') in Band 6 (This is still OK considering the loss in sensitivity in this Band 6 setting). This translates into ~1 hr of integration time (AOT), or about 2.2 hrs in real time.
This sensitivity enables us to: 1) map Io at the highest spatial resolution (Fig. 3; ~8 beams across Io), 2) get high signal-to-noise spectra to derive both the thermal structure and column abundances of SO2, SO across Io, and 3) be able to determine the Dopplershifts of the lines across Io at an accuracy of at least ~10 kHz.
Both the column abundances and gas temperatures are highly uncertain (reported column densities range from1E16 to a few E17 for SO2; reported gas temperatures range from 120 to ~400 K). To determine the spatial distribution of species we can combine several channels, if necessary (as in Fig. 3); to analyze the spectral line profiles, we can integrates over a larger area on the disk, if necessary (we do need to keep the spectral resolution to determine winds and the line shape for atmospheric modeling.

Time constraints: Io should be observed near eastern and western elongation. Timings in C36-6n are provided. After the first time is chosen, the opposite elongation should be in the timeframe approximately nx21.228 hrs later, with n=1,3,5,7,9,11, etc

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Science Goal Band 7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Determine the ratio KCl/NaCl, and map all four gases to determine their sources.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
In Band 7 we observe SO2, SO, NaCl and KCl simultaneously to determine both the ratio NaCl/KCl and the position of these gases relative to SO and SO2 on the disk.
We choose a resolution (Hanning-smoothed) of 122 kHz, which let's us resolve the lines, necessary for our radiative transfer modeling and determination of Doppler shifts to construct velocity fields.

We request the C36-6n array to both get a high spatial resolution (0.10'') and simultaneously see the entire disk (~1'' across). This spatial resolution is neeeded to determine potential differenes in the location of SO2 an SO gases, and connect them to volcanoes on Io, as will be observed quasi-simultaneously in the infrared, at spatial resolutions of ~0.05-0.1'' (Gemini, VLT, Keck).
With observations spread out over 2 hrs in time, longitudes will be smeared over 16 deg, or 0.16'' at disk-center. We will correct for longitudinal smearing both by making maps over shorter time intervals, deproject the maps, and combine them properly shifted in longitude. We will al so attempt to correct the UV data, building on our longitude-resolved Jupiter work (see Sault et al., 2004, Icarus 168, 336).

We request the C36-6n array to both get a high spatial resolution (~0.1'') and simultaneously see the entire disk (~1'' across). We request a frequency resolution of 122 kHz. Using Cycle 0 data and our model calculations (Figs. 2, 3) as guidelines, we request a sensitivity of ~6.5 mJy/bm (~6.5 K in 0.1'') in Band 7. This translates into ~1 hr of integration time in each band (AOT), or about 2.2 hrs in real time.
This sensitivity enables us to: 1) map Io at the highest spatial resolution (Fig. 3; ~10 beams across Io), 2) get high signal-to-noise spectra to derive both the thermal structure and column abundances of SO2, SO, NaCl, and KCl across Io, and 3) be able to determine the Dopplershifts of the lines across Io at an accuracy of at least ~10 kHz.
Both the column abundances and gas temperatures are highly uncertain (reported column densities range from1E16 to a few E17 for SO2; reported gas temperatures range from 120 to ~400 K). To determine the spatial distribution of species we can combine several channels, if necessary (as in Fig. 3); to analyze the spectral line profiles, we can integrate over a larger area on the disk, if necessary (we do need to keep the spectral resolution to determine winds and the line shape for atmospheric modeling.

The high spectral resolution, 122 kHz, required for our modeling results in a data rate of 24.42 MB/s, which exceeds the policy value of 12 MB/s by a factor of 2. Unfortunately, we cannot lower the spectral resolution without diminishing the scientific return.

Time constraints: Io should be observed near eastern and western elongation. Timings in C36-6n are provided. After the first time is chosen, the opposite elongation should be in the timeframe approximately nx21.228 hrs later, with n=1,3,5,7,9,11, etc

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We request 2.2 hours of observing time in each of Bands 6 and 7 to observe SO2, SO, NaCl and KCl in Io's atmosphere at high spatial and spectral resolution, at several frequencies: 1) To simultaneously map these species to determine their source regions. 2) To measure and map the gas temperature and column abundance. 3) To determine the wind patterns in Io's atmosphere. These observations will be used to understand the relation between Io's atmosphere with gas plumes, volcanic activity, and surface frost.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
